title: Thermochemistry of the Haber-Bosch Process
summary: The Haber-Bosch process for synthesizing ammonia demonstrates the interplay of thermodynamics and kinetics in industrial chemistry, and its role in feeding the modern world.
content:
Case Study: Thermochemistry of the Haber-Bosch Process

The Haber-Bosch process is arguably the most important chemical process in human history. By synthesizing ammonia (NH₃) from atmospheric nitrogen and hydrogen, it enabled the production of nitrogen fertilizers that now feed roughly half the world's population.

The Reaction

N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g)   ΔH° = −92 kJ/mol

The reaction is exothermic (releases heat) and involves a decrease in moles of gas (4 mol reactants → 2 mol products).

Thermodynamic Analysis

Using the Gibbs free energy equation ΔG° = ΔH° − TΔS°: the negative ΔH° (−92 kJ/mol) favours the forward reaction, but ΔS° is also negative (−198 J/mol·K) because gas moles decrease. At high temperatures, the −TΔS° term becomes large and positive, making ΔG° less negative — the reaction becomes less favourable thermodynamically.

The Industrial Compromise

Low temperatures maximize yield (Le Chatelier's principle) but slow the reaction rate unacceptably. High pressure (150–300 atm) shifts equilibrium toward NH₃. The industrial process operates at 400–500°C with an iron catalyst — a compromise that provides adequate reaction rate while maintaining reasonable equilibrium conversion (~15–25%).

Energy Considerations

The process is energy-intensive, consuming ~1–2% of global energy annually. Improving catalyst efficiency and exploring lower-temperature pathways remain active areas of research in green chemistry.
